user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_get_daemon_info:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN const union MHD_DaemonInfo *
MHD_get_daemon_info (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon,
                     enum MHD_DaemonInfoType info_type,
                     ...)
{
  if (NULL == daemon)
    return NULL;

  mhd_assert ((0 == (daemon->options & MHD_USE_SELECT_INTERNALLY)) || \
              (NULL != daemon->worker_pool) || \
              (MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_valid_handle_ (daemon->tid)));
  mhd_assert (((0 != (daemon->options & MHD_USE_SELECT_INTERNALLY)) &&
               (NULL == daemon->worker_pool)) || \
              (! MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_valid_handle_ (daemon->tid)));

  switch (info_type)
  {
  case MHD_DAEMON_INFO_KEY_SIZE:
    return NULL;   /* no longer supported */
  case MHD_DAEMON_INFO_MAC_KEY_SIZE:
    return NULL;   /* no longer supported */
  case MHD_DAEMON_INFO_LISTEN_FD:
    daemon->daemon_info_dummy_listen_fd.listen_fd = daemon->listen_fd;
    return &daemon->daemon_info_dummy_listen_fd;
  case MHD_DAEMON_INFO_EPOLL_FD:
#ifdef EPOLL_SUPPORT
    daemon->daemon_info_dummy_epoll_fd.epoll_fd = daemon->epoll_fd;
    return &daemon->daemon_info_dummy_epoll_fd;
#else  /* ! EPOLL_SUPPORT */
    return NULL;
#endif /* ! EPOLL_SUPPORT */
  case MHD_DAEMON_INFO_CURRENT_CONNECTIONS:
    if (! MHD_D_IS_THREAD_SAFE_ (daemon))
      MHD_cleanup_connections (daemon);
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
    else if (daemon->worker_pool)
    {
      unsigned int i;
      /* Collect the connection information stored in the workers. */
      daemon->connections = 0;
      for (i = 0; i < daemon->worker_pool_size; i++)
      {
        /* FIXME: next line is thread-safe only if read is atomic. */
        daemon->connections += daemon->worker_pool[i].connections;
      }
    }
#endif
    daemon->daemon_info_dummy_num_connections.num_connections
      = daemon->connections;
    return &daemon->daemon_info_dummy_num_connections;
  case MHD_DAEMON_INFO_FLAGS:
    daemon->daemon_info_dummy_flags.flags = daemon->options;
    return &daemon->daemon_info_dummy_flags;
  case MHD_DAEMON_INFO_BIND_PORT:
    daemon->daemon_info_dummy_port.port = daemon->port;
    return &daemon->daemon_info_dummy_port;
  default:
    return NULL;
  }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
case MHD_DAEMON_INFO_MAC_KEY_SIZE:
    return NULL;   /* no longer supported */

case MHD_DAEMON_INFO_KEY_SIZE:
    return NULL;   /* no longer supported */
explanation: I selected fragments that are likely candidates for unreachable-code issues: the two complex mhd_assert statements (they contain mutually dependent conditions that may imply unreachable branches), all deprecated-return cases (KEY_SIZE, MAC_KEY_SIZE), the EPOLL_FD case that is split by conditional compilation (#ifdef EPOLL_SUPPORT), the CURRENT_CONNECTIONS case that mixes an if/else-if with conditional compilation for thread support (which can alter control flow and produce unreachable/ill-formed else pairing), and the final default return (which may be redundant/unreachable if all enum values are covered). Other fragments in the function (e.g. the simple LISTEN_FD, FLAGS, BIND_PORT cases that just copy a field then return) are straightforward single-path assignments followed immediately by a return and do not present obvious unreachable-code concerns, so they do not need investigation for Rule 2.1.
